description: Probably a variant of fadge (“to fit”), the confectionery sense having evolved from the meaning of “merging together” or “turning out as expected”.

definitionGroups.group: (chiefly uncountable) A type of very sweet candy or confection, usually made from sugar, butter, and milk or cream.

entries.meaning: (countable) A deliberately misleading or vague answer.

examples: Synonyms: nonsense, humbug; see also Thesaurus:nonsense

entries.meaning: (countable) A less than perfect decision or solution; an attempt to fix an incorrect solution after the fact.

verbs.description: fudge (third-person singular simple present fudges, present participle fudging, simple past and past participle fudged)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To try to avoid giving a direct answer.
examples: When I asked them if they had been at the party, they fudged.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To alter something from its true state, as to hide a flaw or uncertainty, deliberately but not necessarily dishonestly or immorally.
examples: The results of the experiment looked impressive, but it turned out the numbers had been fudged.
I had to fudge the lighting to get the color to look good.

entries.meaning: (dated, transitive, intransitive) To botch or bungle something.
To cheat, especially in the game of marbles.
